title: 114_hr6408
content: The "Building Efficiently Act of 2016" may be cited as the short title. It includes an expansion of the new energy efficient home credit. The "Building Efficiently Act of 2016" expands the new energy efficient home credit by defining qualified energy efficient residential rental property and adjusting the cost of construction percentage. The "Building Efficiently Act of 2016" defines qualified energy efficient residential rental property as a new or reconstructed building meeting certification requirements, with original use starting with the taxpayer, and placed in service after the enactment of the Act. The Building Efficiently Act of 2016 outlines requirements for improvements to existing buildings, including meeting certification requirements, commencing original use with the taxpayer, placing the improved building in service after the Act's enactment, and electing to apply the Act to the building. Buildings acquired by purchase must meet certification requirements and be placed in service after the enactment of the Building Efficiently Act of 2016. Certification involves reducing energy consumption through construction, reconstruction, or retrofitting under a designated plan. The Building Efficiently Act of 2016 aims to reduce energy consumption by 40% compared to baseline levels, determined using specific calculation methods. The Building Efficiently Act of 2016 aims to reduce energy consumption by 40% using designated benchmarking tools or certified calculation methods. Related persons are defined as individuals with a connection as outlined in the Act. The Building Efficiently Act of 2016 aims to reduce energy consumption by 40% using benchmarking tools or calculation methods. Related persons are defined as individuals with a connection as outlined in the Act, including members of an affiliated group or those with a relationship described in section 267. Amendments are made to section 45L(d) to reflect these changes. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2015. Elimination of basis reduction for low-income housing properties receiving certain energy benefits. The text discusses amendments to the New Energy Efficient Home Credit and Energy Efficient Commercial Buildings Deduction in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes exceptions for low-income housing properties receiving credits under section 42. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include exceptions for low-income housing properties receiving credits under section 42. These amendments also affect the Energy Credit, with changes to section 50(c) and an effective date of property placed in service after December 31, 2015.
